From Milking Buffaloes For Strengthening Her Arms To Winning CWG Gold - Krishna Poonia Battled Her Way To Success

Krishna Poonia's groundwork for being an athlete did not come from any proper sports training, but from actually helping out in her father's farm since she turned 15. Yes, that is how the story of this discus thrower began.

PTI

Krishna was born in Haryana. She lost her mother at the age of 9 and father was a farmer. The strength in her arms gradually increased as she milked buffaloes and the physical fitness was at a top level. She later married Virender Singh Poonia, a former athlete who coached her once they were married.

Her first taste of success came in 2006 with an Asian Games bronze. After a national gold following that, there were high hopes from her at the 2008 Olympics. But sadly she failed to make it to the finals.

But it was too early to write her off as 2010 saw her clinch bronze at Asiad. However, the real success came in the Commonwealth Games where she won gold and that was just the tonic she needed.

She became the first Indian woman to win a Commonwealth Games gold in track and field events and only the second Indian ever since Milkha Singh won the 440 yards in 1958.

PTI

After failing to win a medal at the 2012 Olympics, Krishna shifted her focus to politics in 2013. But her achievements on the track have never been forgotten. The girl who got strong by milking buffaloes, went on to create history for India on the big stage. A legacy to be proud of.
